text: Wearing longjohns and boots, DAN BUSTS OUT THE DOOR, movi toward the man fanning fire at the barn--

No-- Please-- stop!-- A RIFLE BUTT SMASHES DAN’S HEAD. He tumbles off the porch the dirt, losing his gun, one boot coming off, revealing- A MISSING LEFT FOOT. William runs past Alice and Mark on the porch and his fat on the ground as-- THE BARN EXPLODES IN FLAMES. Dan jerks back on his rigged boot, gets upright and lunges toward the barn. THE FIRST HORSEMAN, bears down on him.
-- You have a week, Evans. Then we burn the house.

head_text.subj: THE HORSEMEN RIDE AWAY AS WILLIAM ENTERS THE FLAMING BARN

text: William!

FOUR HORSES tied in stalls, crazy with fear. William frees two of them, Dan untangles the others and l them out, grabbing equipment, tossing saddles out the doo Then Dan notices WILLIAM HAS TURNED BACK INSIDE. William struggles to drag A HUGE SACK OF FEED and some to We see above him, the burning roof sags, flaming pieces o wood raining-- it’s about to collapse-- DAN LEAPS AND GRABS HIS BOY and drags him toward the door fists swinging. (CONTINUED)
--Let go! It’s the last we got! They fall to the ground as THE BARN COLLAPSES in a fiery mass, sparks showering down. Alice and Mark run toward th

..-You alright? Will turns from his father to see- THE TWO HORSEMEN ridin away. Dawn light beginning to touch the sky. WILLIAM LUNGES FOR THE REMINGTON on the ground-- --but Dan is faster and puts his hand on the weapon.
I’ll take care of this.
No you won’t. ...You don’t take care of nothing. Tears stand in William’s eyes. Dan takes the gun and starts walking back toward the hous He passes Alice and Mark, avoiding their eyes.
The herd is over the ridge by now. Get cleaned up.

Dan yanks open a drawer and grabs a shirt. His arms and c streaked in SOOT... Out the bedroom window the sun is creeping over the rocky horizon. His eyes fall upon a beautiful ANTIQUE BROOCH in a drawer He examines it. It is gold. And he pockets it and turns, finding himself looking at William, watching him. William turns away, and crosses to his bedroom. Dan moves to a basin at the back of the house.
You lied to me, Dan. Dan turns to face Alice. ALICE (CONT’D) You told me we made payments to Hollander. (CONTINUED)
We did. Some. (off look, heading inside) How do you think we bought feed, Alice? Three months water. Medicine for Mark. I had a choice between our family and paying it down.
We’ re supposed to make decisions together.
Would you have made it different?
Dan.

We can’t make it rain together. Or turn dust into grass. And we can’t hold back winter. It’s too bad the doctors at Essex saved so much of my leg. I read the pension act pays by the pound now. Dan leans against the wall, pulling on his boots. Tears come to Alice’s eyes.
Stop looking at me like that. Mark appears in the hall. Dan crosses back to his bedroom pulling on a clean shirt.
(as Dan passes) .»..You gonna tell the Marshal what those men did?
(from his bedroom) Marshal ain’t doing shit.
William.
First thing I’m gonna do, Mark, is take you boys and round up the herd. ...Then I’m going to town. (CONTINUED)
CLOSE ON-- WILLIAM in his room, gettting dressed, listeni with jaundice as his father reassures Mark. He pockets a of cards and his dime novel.
What you gonna do in town?
I’m gonna tell Hollander to make this right. I’m gonna tell him he needs to pay for a new barn.
Maybe we should just shoot him, like Will says. Alice meets eyes with Dan who grabs HIS SPENCER RIFLE and brushes past William on his way to the door.
....-Let’s go. We got cattle to get.

--atop a magnificent BLACK MARE, staring at something. Be has a ruggedly handsome face, but what strikes you first his focus. He’s very still, eyes on fire, low to the hors The horse inches forward. Hooves hardly make a sound. REVERSE TO REVEAL-- A RED-TAILED HAWK, perched only fifte feet away on the limb of a dead tree.

ANGLE ON-- WADE makes a low ‘s’ sound and his horse halts Wade sketches the bird on A SMALL LEDGER PAD with a PENCI capturing its form with quick gestures. Suddenly: A noise The hawk FLIES OFF. Wade watches it shrink into the sky. A darkness fills his eyes. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: CHARLIE PRINCE (31), a pale eyed out coming up behind Wade. A PAIR OF SCHOFIELDS on his legs. ...he stops his horse respectfully, a few yards back.
Coach is headed for Bisbee, Boss. Girded with iron. Pinks on top. Double shotguns and a Gatlin-- (CONTINUED)

Charlie trails off as Wade rides to the tree, tears his SKETCH and pins it to a BRANCH where the hawk had been perched. His eyes flick to-- A DISTANT STAGECOACH, a speck in the valley, kicking dust Wade turns his horse and trots past Charlie... Charlie Prince glances at the drawing. HOLD ON: THE SKETC FLUTTERING IN THE BREEZE as Prince follows down the hill.

Charlie Prince follows as-- Ben Wade rides down past a CLUSTER OF BOULDERS where his outfit awaits him: JORGENSEN (45): Massive arms and legs. A bear of a man. CAMPOS (38): The marksman. Loads a cradled MONSTER RIFLE. KINTER (34): A soulless butcher with deadened eyes. SUTHERLAND (42): An explosives expert. He supervises as-- TIGHE (28): his protege, loading TNT in a saddle bag. JACKSON (35): Powerful and dangerous. A friend and former cellmate of -- TOMMY DARDEN (28): Battle-scarred handsome face. A BOWIE KNIFE in his hand. He is looking to replace Wade and lead gang someday, soon. But in the meantime, he amuses himsel making trouble with-- NEZ (32): An Apache renegade. He speaks little English an uses it rarely. But he is a great shot, a brilliant rider a merciless fighter. He’s been with Wade since the beginn Darden taunts Nez with his long knife, oblivious to Wade’ approach-- He and Jackson trade a chuckle. Nez looks at Wade. And Wade looks at Darden hard.
Ben. Darden slips the knife back in the sheaf. Wade turns his eyes to the road below. ...and here comes the STAGECOACH, GETTING CLOSER. (CONTINUED)

Wade turns to Charlie and gives a nod... ...and the gang surges behind Charlie Prince. As everyone rides past him, Campos the marksman looks back to Wade. W nods to a CLUSTER OF BOULDERS nearby. Campos climbs off his horse and scales the rocks.

CLOSE ON: GALLOPING HOOVES thundering down a desert road. A team of FOUR HORSES pulling an ARMORED STAGECOACH throu barren stretch of land. We see a fancy EYE LOGO stamped upon the door with the fa Pinkerton slogan printed below: The Eye That Never Sleeps There are SIX PINKERTONS riding. Two in front, two ona mounted “tailgun” platform and two inside, peering out sl THE VETERAN DRIVER pushes the horses. Sitting beside him is the sixth man and the group’s leade BYRON McELROY (55). McElroy is clearly not a Pinkerton, a hardly dressed or groomed like one. He’s got snake-like e He holds a mean-looking, twelve-gauge HAMMER SHOTGUN.

Dan’s crouched next to his horse, gazing at one of his co which has collapsed upon the arid earth, gasping... Dan glances up at the sky, then he pulls out the BROOCH i his grimy hands. Twenty feet away, William sits on his horse behind Dan, shuffling HIS DECK OF CARDS.
You gonna hock that? Dan pockets it.
Someday, William. You walk in my shoes, you might understand.
I’m never walking in your shoes. (CONTINUED)
Mark calls out from a nearby ridge:
Tracks over here! Dan takes the SPENCER RIFLE from his saddle. Standing ove the dying creature. Looking in its eyes as he FIRES...
The SHOT ECHOES faintly through the foothills. Wade peers around behind him. He shrugs it off, focusing back on his outfit below.
McElroy stiffens as-- WADE’S GANG appears suddenly on the road ahead coming straight at the coach, head on. McElroy sees them and grimaces. Cocking both pins on his SHOTGUN.

Here we go. With proficiency, the other Pinkertons flip down or slide across several ARMORED STEEL PLATES in front of them.. ...and in the next second, the outlaws and the Pinkertons clash in a violent FUSILLADE OF BULLETS. TWO PINKERTONS MAN THE GATLIN mounted at the rear. Unfortunately it is exactly where the gang isn’t (they’re coming from the front) and they have no shot. The Pinkertons fire as Wade’s gang rides straight at them game of chicken. Bullets exploding around him, McELROY AIMS AT ONE OF THE OUTLAWS RIDING IN FRONT. -- BANG! -- With one shot he blows the outlaw off his hor As the gang swarms around them -- RATATATAT. PINKERTONS F THE GATLIN, spraying the gang, mowing down another outlaw Suddenly, one of the Pinkertons on the gatlin falls back, shot by-- CAMPOS, at his sniper’s perch-- rifle smoking. The remaining Pinkerton cradles the ammo and swings the b brass gun at Campos, twisting the crank. (CONTINUED)

Campos dives for cover amid a hail of bullets. Like fighter pilots, the gang wheels in unison back aroun catch the coach on another pass. CHARLIE PRINCE GALLOPS from the other side of the coach a takes out the remaining Gatlin operator with two shots.

McElroy and the Pinkertons defend the coach valiantly. Ta cover behind their ARMORED PLATES as the coach rattles al the road. Another Pinkerton climbs from a hatch and re-ma the Gatlin. He sends a spray of bullets toward the oncomi gang-- another man falls. The last Pinkerton (MOONS) inside the stagecoach takes ai through the gun slit. He manages to HIT JORGENSEN. The big man snaps backwards, falling to the ground, while clutching HIS EAR... CLOSE ON -- MCELROY’S EYES watching Sutherland and Tighe approach from the driver’s side.

(to driver) Get. Down. Now! McElroy swings his shotgun over the driver, who ducks, an aims at Tighe but then aims lower, at his saddle bag-- He fires and-- BOOM!-- TIGHE AND HORSE EXPLODE IN MID-STR THE COACH LURCHES INTO A NARROW PASS, making it hard for gang to follow.

Wade watches, amused, his eyes on McElroy as he directs t coach to make a run for a narrow pass. Wade smiles. These two have history. Then, he notices-- A SCRAWNY HERD OF CATTLE on the other side of an outcroppin Forty cows and bulls nibbling on what little they can fin A thought flickers across Wade’s mind. And he abruptly wheels his horse towards the animals.  14 15 16
Dan and his sons have stopped their horses over the ridge listening to the GUNSHOTS. Sounds like a warzone. Dan pulls out his SPENCER RIFLE, riding in front.
Stay behind me.
THE STAGECOACH RACES through the narrow pass, A PLUME OF rising. McElroy squints, seeing-- A HERD OF CATTLE stampeding toward him. And Ben Wade driv them unflinchingly with a stock whip.

Pull up, kid. Pull up! The driver stares at the cattle, frozen. Imagine the bull in Pamplona, only you’re driving into it. McElroy lunges the reins pulling hard as HOOVES and HORNS collide. The STAGECOACH lists to one side, you can feel the weight this iron carriage. The FRONT AXLE SNAPS. Horses break fr The STAGECOACH NOSES INTO AN EMBANKMENT AND FLIPS, rollin end over end like a semi on the turnpike. McElroy, the driver, and injured Pinkertons catapult to the air. ANGLE ON: THE OUTLAWS hounding unfortunate survivors. Darden touches his BOWIE KNIFE to the chest of A PINKERTO
Oh God, Mr. Wade. Please. I got a wife and three kids. Please don’t--
What did you call me, boy? I ain’t Ben Wade. My name is Tommy Darden. Legend with a blade. Soon to run this outfit. Say my name. Say it.
...I can’t remember it... (CONTINUED)
Darden twists the knife as the driver howls. Charlie Prince wields his TWO SCHOFIELDS like the Reaper, singing and doing a soft shoe as he puts two Pinkertons o of their misery.
moves slowly, confidently toward the coach, unimpressed b the carnage. Most of the coach horses have run off. A cou are on the ground. A few cattle wander about dazed.
As the dust settles. The outlaws find McElroy pulling him in the dirt, holding his leg, reaching with his other han for his HAMMER SHOTGUN.
Morning, Pinkerton. Name’s Charlie Prince. I expect you heard of me.

I heard of a balled-up whore named Charlie Princess. That you, missy. Darden and Jackson get a chuckle out of this -- Charlie Prince smiles, then fires a SHOT into McElroy’s gut... ...and McElroy just GRUNTS.
I hate Pinkertons. ANGLE ON: BEN WADE riding up now, the gang clearing a pat He stops before McElroy and they share a look...

When’d your hair turn all gray, Byron. McElroy says nothing. Wade gives a nod to Sutherland who rushes up to the PADLOCKED STEEL DOOR on the stagecoach, SATCHEL OF EXPLOSIVES under his arm. (CONTINUED)

I heard, Byron, that your boss, Al Pinkerton, president of the most feared protection agency in all the world, home of the eye that never sleeps, well, I heard he got an infection from biting his own tongue ...and died last month. That true? (turns) Makes you think, don’t it Charlie? (CONTINUED)
Some of the gang laughs. As Sutherland sets EXPLOSIVES, W circles the toppled coach, admiring the ARMORED PLATES.
Al spared no expense on this one, Byron. Probably cheaper just to let me rob the damned thing.
If you’re gonna kill me, I’d just as soon get to it.
(dismounts) I’m not gonna kill you. Not like this.
You let me live, it won’t change a thing. I’1l come for you.

Be disappointed if you didn’t. BOOM! THE EXPLOSIVES blow the STEEL DOOR off its hinges. Moons lies, groggy and bloody on the floor. Darden jumps past Sutherland and inside the stagecoach (stepping over Moons, who plays dead). He reappears with STRONG BOX. He shoots off the PADLOCK and OPENS the box.. ...to reveal DOZENS OF CASH ROLLS inside. Railroad money. whoops with joy, tossing the CASH ROLLS to Jackson who pu the CASH ROLLS into SADDLE BAGS. Wade watches the pair closely.

...From the crest of the ridge, Mark waves to Dan and William. Mark sees the HERD and the STAGECOACH WRECKAGE, OUTLAWS swarming around it. Coming up the rise, Dan goes still at the sight of this. He signals silence to Mark. Mark’s horse fidgets. Some rocks tumble down the ridge.  20 21 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 13.

...the robbery is almost over now. Darden emptying out th last of the STRONG BOX. Nez packing the CASH in SADDLE BA Wade glances at the wounded Jorgensen who’s tied a BANDAN around his ear. He gives the boss a nod, he’s okay. All of a sudden ...CLICK! Darden freezes, hearing a PISTO from behind. The rest of the gang goes still, guns ready. Moons climbs out from inside the coach, grabbing Darden, hostage-style. He is a blood drenched mess.
I’1l ask you to put down the money.
‘not a good play, friend.
...Step back now. All of you. Hands up. Or he dies. No one in the gang moves a muscle. Darden tries to free himself but Moons holds tight, cocking his weapon to Dard temple. Darden looks at Wade.

...Shit. -- Wade quick-draws his COLT “PEACEMAKER” -- BANG! -- AND SHOOTS DARDEN who spins violently-- grabbing his NECK and falling to the ground, mortally wounded. BANG! ANOTHER SHOT snaps Moons’ head back. He falls to the ground, dead.
It’s obviously the first time the children have ever seen killing. Mark is shaken... William fascinated... ...and we see that Dan’s all too aware of this.
He is fast... (CONTINUED)
Back up. Quietly. William. Rocks start to slide as Dan moves them to a less exposed point.
BACK AT THE COACH, WADE reloads his smoking pistol as he speaks to Darden stuggling for last breaths on the dirt.

...Well, Tommy. It appears there was a Pink in that coach you didn’t see. Now I don’t know if Charlie told you, but we got a few rules in this outfit. And this sad outcome, well, this is what happens when you put us all at risk. You were weak. Some rocks fall in the distance, from where Dan and his s are making a retreat. A boy coughs. The whole gang hears

Ten guns whip to the ridge. Cocked and leveled at Dan. Wade leaps on his his horse, GALLOPING up to the ridge WI CHARLIE PRINCE AND CAMPOS RIGHT BEHIND HIM. Jackson starts to pick up the money... ...but Nez gets th first. Placing the SADDLE BAGS full of cash onto his hors The other outlaws watch him.
Dan rides in front of his two boys as Wade and Charlie Pr approach. Wade and Dan stare at one another.
Morning.
Those are my cattle. I want them back.
Careful, rancher. That’s Ben Wade you’re talking to. (CONTINUED)
We see William, awestruck.
I need them back. They’re all I’ve got.
I don’t want your herd. But I’m going to need those horses. (CONTINUED)
(moves forward) So you don’t do anything foolish. Dan sheaths his rifle and gives his boys a look. They dismount and Charlie Prince takes their horses.
You'll find them on the trail to Bisbee. The two outlaws turn, taking the horses, riding down the leaving Dan his boys.
...we FOLLOW Wade, Prince and Campos as they ride away.
(quietly, to Prince) What’s in Bisbee.
‘Aint you thirsty. Charlie rides past the WRECKAGE and the gang falls in beh Charging down the road. Jackson lags, circling Darden’s b

Minutes later. Dan leads his sons through the cattle whic are milling about the WRECKAGE. Dan looks for survivors. DEAD BODIES. A few DEAD STEER. And one of the HORSES that pulled the coach, also dead. William spots something by Bill Moons’ corpse... Three SPENT SHELLS from WADE’S PISTOL. William picks up o of the spent shells. Gazing at it like it’s treasure. ANGLE ON: DAN as he comes upon McElroy in the dirt, bleeding... trying to get up...
Ahhh Dammit! (to Dan) Get me on my feet. (CONTINUED)
I think you’re in pretty bad shape, Mister. Maybe you should--
Get me on my damned feet! ...-As Dan tries to lift him, McElroy grunts and gets upr but then his legs give out and he crumbles to the ground.
Mark, William-- (pointing to the wreck) Bring me one of them boards.

Ben Wade rides, shadowed by Charlie Prince on his horse. The rest of the gang is nowhere in sight... ...the two men are approaching a remote town -- A dozen WOODEN STRUCTURES strewn upon a crossroad. Small flags stuck in the dirt, trace the intended path of train line from the mountains. A sign says: ANNOUNCING THE BISBEE-CONTENTION LINE. A small surveying crew works, laying out the flags.

THE OUTLAWS survey the town as they ride through. There’s SALOON (“Hollander’s”) and around the corner A VETERINARI OFFICE and a BLACKSMITH. A FEW TOWNSFOLK move along, none paying much attention. EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY At the end of the street sits the MARSHAL’S OFFICE, sever horses tied to the side. Wade dismounts at the corner, noticing a BARMAID emerge from a saloon... ...this is EMMA NELSON (31). She glances at Wade, meeting eyes, then turns to sweep the porch. A connection. (CONTINUED)

Charlie Prince ties his horse further down the block from Wade. He glances at Sutherland across the street, tending his horse near a Blacksmith’s shop. Off Wade’s glance, Charlie starts to the Marshals’s offic FOLLOWING CHARLIE’S BOOTS-- With each step, his gait chan from the stride of an outlaw to the amble of a cowpoke. INT./EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY In the doorway looking out, GRAYSON BUTTERFIELD (36) star at the horizon. His face sour with anxiety. He wears the official suit of the Southern Railroad. Just inside MARSHAL WEATHERS (42) checks his watch. HIS DEPUTY, KANE, rolls a cigarette in the back.
They’ re probably just late, Mister Butterfield. Charlie Prince leans in the doorway.
Pinkertons don’t run late, Marshal. That’s why they’re paid fourteen dollars a day.
Can I help you?
...Well ...I think maybe a coach headed for here got itself held up in a canyon ten miles back. By Ben Wade himself, I think.
God Dammit!..

How did you know it was Wade? OUTSIDE-- BEN WADE watches as-- Emma crosses inside the saloon with her dust pan. Ben pulls his hat low and walks down the plank sidewalk, moving closer to the voices in the Marshal’s office... (CONTINUED)
‘Can’t say I know it was him. But I saw a Mexican sharpshooter, and an Apache.
...desus Christ. Did you see the “Hand of God”?
...What’s that?
His pistol.
Why didn’t you do something?

There was a lot of weapons, Mister. And they was shooting bullets. The Marshal and Kane grab their rifles and move to the do Butterfield follows. EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE-- CONTINUOUS The Marshal and others blow right by Prince as they mount their horses. Wade watches from up the street.
(to Prince) Where you fellas from anyway?

Prairie Cattle Company. Boss purchased ten thousand head in Mexico, hired us to drive them in. The Marshal nods, satisfied and spurs his horse, gallopin off, down the street. INT. HOLLANDER’S MERCANTILE -- CONTINUOUS Watching out a window, TUCKER (last seen burning Dan’s ba watches the Marshal and Butterfield ride off.
Something’s going on with the railroad man. (CONTINUED)
GLENN HOLLANDER (45), the town’s well-groomed saloon owne and entrepreneur looks up from his inventory.

Seeing the street is clear, Charlie Prince nods to Wade. Wade crosses, heading toward the saloon doors. Charlie follows, passing a look to Sutherland. And Sutherland nods to-- Campos, who’s in an alley with Jorgensen, helping the big man hold a bloody rag to his damaged ear. Sutherland also signals Kinter and Nez behind the saloon. One by one, the outlaws amble toward the saloon.

Wade peers over the SALOON DOORS. The place is empty save old timer. A few tables and chairs, with a bar on one wal Emma turns to see Wade. She keeps her eyes on him as he s inside, his crew following. Most come in from the BACK DO Campos and Jackson escort the old timer out. Wade takes a place at the head of the bar...
Whiskey. Emma starts pouring them each a shot of WHISKEY. Gradually working her way up to Wade.
Here’s to the boss. He leads us to the loot and to success. We lost three men today and that’s too bad.

Two died fighting. One was weak. We’ re only as strong as our weakest. Tommy was weak. Wade downs his shot with the men. He turns and meets eyes with Jackson. Jackson looks away. With Nez’s help, Charlie distributes shares from the day’ job. A stack of cash to each man. It is a careful process Charlie looks at Wade and Emma, then looks to Nez. (CONTINUED)

Nez gets up and leads the gang out the back door. Wade’s eyes hold on Emma. Charlie leans beside him. CHARLIE PRINCE (CONT’D) That Marshal’s only half stupid. He’s gonna be back soon. Wade just looks at him. Outside the window, the gang rides off. CHARLIE PRINCE (CONT’D) They’ re going across the border. I won’t be far. I’1l wait for you.
Okay, Charlie. Charlie exits. Wade finishes his drink. Emma cleans.
I’ve seen you someplace before.
Have you.
You ever work for a blind Irishman in Dodge City.
I was a singer. Best time I ever had, my whole life.
What made you quit. Emma turns away, collecting the SHOT GLASSES... ..-and Wade follows her around the counter.
I got to coughing too much. Doctor said I should find a drier climate.
I spent more money in that joint, I tell you. Remember a girl, her name was Velvet. (CONTINUED)
(her back to him) Nobody forgets Velvet. Wade reaches out and touches the back of her neck... Emma hasn’t been touched like that in a while.
You know, you look kind of skinny.
I feel skinny.
That’s all right. I don’t mind skinny girls, long as they have green eyes to make up for it. Do you have green eyes. She turns, showing him her BROWN EYES...
That’s all right... They don’t have to be green.

Dan and William carry McElroy along a trail on a STRETCHE made of a stagecoach panel. Dan’s in front. Mark walks alongside, glancing at McElroy’s WOUND. McElro clutches a rag to it and glares at the sky, muttering.
...You think they lied? You think they stole our horses.
Ben Wade don’t need our shit horses.
Watch your mouth. Cresting a ridge, they come upon-- Their horses tied to a tree. Dan is surprised.
William helps his father prop a growling McElroy onto Dan horse. As Mark mounts up. Dan turns to William. (CONTINUED)
...Take your brother and round up the cattle. Don’t push them. I can’t afford any more dropping. William spits, looking at something, then mounts his hors
...Here comes the Cavalry. Dan turns to see-- Marshal Weathers riding up with Kane, Crawley and Butterfield. He turns back to his son.
Do as I said. William spurs his horse and leads Mark off, looking back Butterfield dismounts, crossing to McElroy.
He from the coach?
The only one who made it. It was Ben Wade.
Mister McElroy. Can you hear me. He needs attention.
Get him on my horse.
You see which way they rode, Evans?
Looked like they were headed to Bisbee... With dark faces, Butterfield looks to the Marshal and the realize...

INT. EMMA’S BEDROOM-- SALOON - DAY Wade relaxes on a chair, wearing only pants. He sketches who’s lounging naked in bed in a small room above the sal She watches him work for several moments, grinning. (CONTINUED)

His eyes meet hers. There are sparks between these two. S rolls toward him. He reaches out -- touches her ivory ski Out a window, Wade glances at-- Butterfield, Dan, the Mar and his Deputies riding into town, McElroy in tow. Wade turns away from the window. It doesn’t worry him.
...There’s a town south of the border... A pretty little pueblucho on the river. Folks would pay good money there to hear a white woman sing.
....Yeah, imagine me shinning down to Mexico with Ben Wade on my arm.
I’m not wanted in Mexico. Emma studies him, wondering if he’s sincere. She breaks a smile, like he’s pulling her leg. But his eyes are still.
Jump out that back window with me. Emma stares at him, mystified, then laughs.

You’ re crazy. She smiles and starts to rolls out of bed, but he pulls h back to him and into the soft bed. INT. DOC POTTER’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY A loud knocking. DOC POTTER (42) shuffles toward the door UNLOCKS it. Kane and Dan move in holding McElroy in their arms. Butterfield follows. Dan sets McElroy on a BIG SLAB
Coach got held up.
What’s his name.
Byron McElroy. He’s a bounty hunter under contract with the Pinkertons. (CONTINUED)
Butterfield looks about the room. A veterinarian's office crosses to the window. Outside the saloon, the Marshal and Crawley begin to sear the village for Wade.
(crossing to the door) I best get out there.
You've lost a lot of blood, Mister McElroy. I’m gonna need to do a little stitching on your--

Shut your mouth and do the same to my gut. Doc Potter blinks. He notes the many scarred-over bullet holes and gashes on McElroy’s chest. Dan crosses to the door, watching as-- Kane joins the Marshal and Crawley as they continue movin through the town, guns drawn.
DOC POTTER (CONT’D) What I’m about to do is going to hurt like a sonofabitch... (to Butterfield) ...-Hold him please. Butterfield moves to pin McElroy, but...

Don’t touch me. Doc Potter dives a LONG PAIR OF TWEEZERS into McElroy’s wound. McElroy grunts fiercely, eyes welling, holding his glare with Potter. Plink. The bullet’s out. Doc Potter drops it in a dish. McElroy turns, noticing the ANIMAL CHARTS on all the wall
What the fuck kind of Doctor are you anyway? (CONTINUED)
Nice to have a conversation with a patient once in a while.
Dan makes his way around the corner from Potter’s place, moving toward Hollander’s mercantile. He sees-- Hollander talking to a clerk, through an open side door. Dan steps pick up speed.
Crawley stops in front of Wade’s Horse, runs his hand ove the animal. This animal is not from Bisbee

The Marshal and Kane stand at the entrance of the saloon. They look about until they hear a whistle from outside. They turn to see-- Crawley pointing to Wade’s horse in fr of the Boarding House. They move quickly to the Boarding House, weapons drawn.

INT. HOLLANDER’S MERCANTILE -- CONTINUOUS Dan enters. He meets eyes with Tucker, who assists a cler with inventory. On the other side of the room, Hollander a Ledger book in his bag and pulls on his coat, watching his window.
What the hell are they looking for?
...-Ben Wade. He held up the payroll coach. I was there.
Fuck off, cripple.
I want to talk, Mister Hollander. (CONTINUED)
Hollander moves toward the door, his eyes across the stre watching the search. He checks his sidearm.
Ben Wade in Bisbee. Shit. We’re moving up.
Mister Hollander.
(to Tucker) ‘Going to the saloon... Dan follows Hollander out the door.
Dan trails after Hollander along the plank walkway.
...You got no right to do what you done. You hear me. That’s my land.
Come next week, its not, Evans. You borrowed a good deal of money. And I got rights to recompense. Dan grabs Hollander by the collar--
.»..You dammed up my creek. You shut off my water. How am I supposed to-- Tucker come from behind, grabbing Dan, throwing him backw Hollander dusts himself off.
...Before water touches your land, Evans, it resides and flows on mine, and, as such, I can do with it as I fucking please. Go home and pack up. Dan holds out ALICE’S BROOCH.
...Let me just get to spring. I can turn the corner. CLOSE ON -- HOLLANDER, glancing at it. Not enough. (CONTINUED)

...Sometimes, a man has to be big enough to see how small he is. The railroads coming. Your land is worth more with you off it. Hollander turns and climbs the steps and moves through th saloon doors, disappearing into an office inside. Tucker watches Dan until he starts to walk toward his hor in front of Doc Potter’s place. CLOSE ON-- DAN. Fire in his eyes, he adjusts his saddle, waiting for Tucker to head around the corner, Then, he gr his SPENCER RIFLE and marches for the saloon entrance. CLOSE ON-- THE MARSHAL, catching sight of Dan.
What the hell...
Ben Wade slips past Emma, out her bedroom door, moving toward the stairs. But his hand moves to his PEACEMAKER w he hears--

Hollander! Emma and Wade meet eyes. Wade proceeds down the spiral stairs to see-- Dan, wild-eyed, holding his rifle, standing at the door t leads to Hollander’s office... Wade approaches Dan. Dan steps toward the bar.
You look a little bent, Rancher. You come to wake some snakes? Emma crosses down the stairs.
Dan. Would you like a drink.
No thanks. (CONTINUED)
Dan looks at Wade. Heart is in his throat. Sweat on his b What is he doing here?
...-You got your horses back, didn’t you? And your herd? Dan?
You killed two of them. Wade smiles. He places SIX GOLD COINS on the bar.
They were thin. But this should cover it. Dan doesn’t respond. Over Wade’ shoulder, he sees Crawley the windows, moving toward the back of the saloon. WADE (CONT’D) What’s a day’s work worth to you?
I get two dollars when I hire out.
Here’s two for half a day. Wade puts TWO MORE COINS on the bar...
You took up my boys’ time too. Wade adds another two. Shares a look with Emma.

Anything else you want to get paid for, Dan? Dan fingers the GOLD COINS. His eyes flick, seeing the Marshal enetering from the back door. Leveling a SLIDE-AC REPEATER at Wade’s back. Wade is about to turn when--
If it’s alright with you, you can give me five dollars extra.
For what.
...For making me nervous. (CONTINUED)
Wade’s face changes, something wrong. CLICK-CLACK. Marshal Weathers cocks his REPEATER behind W Digging the muzzle into the his back.
Hands up, Ben Wade. Tucker appear in the SALOON DOORS, PISTOL drawn.
Boss. Boss! Crawley and Kane come in behind the Marshal. Hollander emerges fromn his office. Tucker hoots, thrilled.
Ben Wade captured in Bisbee! The outlaw glares at Dan who lets out a breath. He keeps his eyes on him as he raises his hands in the ai
Laugh while you can. Kane grabs Wade’s Peacemaker as Crawley locks a pair of H CUFFS on his wrists. the Marshall grabs Crawley--
Get the wagon and make sure every weapon we got is shoot ready. I’1l meet you out front of the office. (to the others) We got to get him out of here.
We should shoot him right now. Put a bullet in his noggin.

You do that, every man, woman and child in this shit-piss town will be slaughtered by daybreak. Dan and the others look to-- Byron McElroy in the doorway. Blood seeps from the bandag around his gut. He holds his shotgun. Potter trails after him, trying to finish his dressing. (CONTINUED)

(pointing at Wade) Twenty two robberies. Four hundred thousand in losses, more in delays. The Southern Pacific wants Ben Wade convicted in a Federal Court. Hung in public. An example made. And we will pay to make it happen.
(to Dan) You notice he never mentioned the lives I’ve taken?
I need three more men. (grabs Wade) Let’s go. The Marshal escorts Wade toward the door.
You can have Tucker.
I’m coming. So you need only one.
You’ re wounded, Mister McElroy.
I can ride a goddam horse as easy as I can sit here.
He knows Wade. You need him.
If he goes, Potter’s coming.
Doc can’t shoot shit.
I was the best shot in my regiment. I’ll come. For two hundred dollars. Everybody turns to Dan--
You fight for the North or South? (CONTINUED)
Dan looks at the Southern Railroad pin on Butterfield’s jacket. Still, he can’t lie.
...North.
We’re Southern in name, but Chicago owned. (to the others) Fine. Two hundred.
Thank you.
Thank me when its done.
Dan watches as the Marshal ushers Wade across the street. Nearby, Crawley and Kane hustle to prepare a stagecoach, tying chain around it to secure the doors.
Hurry up, Kane. CRACK! A SHOT RINGS OUT. It’s Charlie Prince, tearing dow the street on his horse, a SMOKING SCHOFIELD PISTOL in hi hands. He gallops down main street, townspeople clearing.

This town’s gonna burn! THE OUTLAW GALLOPS PAST. Never slowing. He fires twice-- BANG, BANG! The first shot drops DEPUTY KANE right in front of the co The second shot takes down A RANDOM BISBEE MAN. Eeryone uinloads their weapons-- BANG BANG BANGG-- as Cha scoots away on his horse, into the hills.
EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY Marshal Weathers muscles Wade to a waiting CARRIAGE tied chains and padlocked. Both of them spot -- (CONTINUED)

Charlie prince-- perched on his horse a half mile out of town, watching what happens to his boss. Wade gives him a and Charlie Prince nods back. The marshal shoves Wade inside the coach, then, as he cli onto the driver’s seat-- Emma comes up to the door.
Were you sincere about Mexico?
(smiles) -No. ...WE PULL BACK ON: Emma and the rest of the Bisbee towns as they stand back and watch the COACH take Wade away.
Marshal Weathers hauls ass along a CATTLE TRAIL, ever awa that Charlie Prince is following him on the ridge like a trailing its master...

DAN’S CATTLE are back in the holding yard. Dan stands on porch with Alice. His two boys inside, pressed against th windows. WHAT THEY SEE: THE PRISON WAGON is passing their ranch, crossing a CRUDE BRIDGE over a dry creek bed. They also s Charlie Prince crest a nearby bluff, watching the wagon.

text: Inside the wagon, Wade glances at his HAND CUFFS and grin self-assuredly. He notices a tear in the seat. A PIECE OF COPPER WIRING sticking out. All of a sudden, the PRISON WAGON LURCHES TO A STOP. One the wheels has skidded off A CRUDE BRIDGE.  60 61 62 63 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 33.

text: Marshal Weathers curses, leaps down and attempts to free wheel. Wade glances out through the chained door, watching the marshal’s futile struggle... ...finally, Marshal Weathers turns to Dan on the porch.
Hello, there. Evans. Can you give me a hand with this.
On cue, Dan walks out. Tucker and Crawley follow.
Whatever your wife is cooking in there smells good, Evans. Tucker and Crawley laugh.
Charlie Prince squints to get a look at what’s going on a the men from the ranch disappear behind the listing PRISO WAGON and begin to push it back up onto the bridge.

text: Wade quickly pockets the length of COPPER WIRING as Marsh Weathers discreetly UNLOCKS the prison wagon door and hau Wade out. Crawley exchanges hats with the outlaw... ...-now Marshal Weathers gives Tucker the key to WADE’S H CUFFS. We see Tucker placing the key in his shirt pocket.

Remind me never to play cards in this town. Crawley now takes Wade’s place inside the PRISON WAGON... ...and Marshal Weathers PADLOCKS the door again. Wade wat the men finally push the PRISON WAGON back onto the bridg  64 65 66 67 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 34.
The switch has taken just a few fast seconds -- and from vantage point on the bluff, Charlie Prince is none the wi

text: Marshal Weathers resumes his seat on the PRISON WAGON...
Thanks for your help, Dan.
You gonna check on my family when you come back, right?
First thing. Let’s go. Ya! The coach rides off, fast, leaving Wade behind with them. A cloud of dust rises.
Thinking Wade’s still in the PRISON WAGON, Charlie Prince wheels his horse around, GALLOPING away from the ranch...
.»..as Dan and Tucker lead Wade up to the porch. McElroy Butterfield appear in the doorway. Wade nods to Alice, bu she glares. McElroy pushes Wade inside...
How long’s he have to stay.
An hour. Make sure Wade’s outfit takes the bait.
What happens if they catch the wagon.
You saw where his man was. He’s still got to fetch the outfit. They should get to the Fort before dawn. (CONTINUED)
His gang can’t do anything in front of the whole Sixth Cavalry.
Doc Potter keeps watch on Dan’s porch with Tucker. Both m cradling RIFLES in their laps. Doc Potter stares at the smouldering wreck of the old bar
You have something to do with that? (off Tucker’s smirk) Hope you’re proud of yourself.
...-Doing my job, Doc.

Inside, Alice prepares dinner. The two boys carry plates the table where Butterfield is waiting... ...we see William, starstruck, offering a plate to Wade w sitting at the end of the table. He smiles a thanks. McEl sits next to the outlaw, his HAMMER SHOTGUN in his hands. Dan sits at the other end of the table, joining Alice and sons. He notices William staring at Wade. Wade nods to William and digs into his food. Then Wade looks up, no on else is eating.
We always wait to say Grace.
And we don’t presume to teach other people manners.
Aren’t we supposed to say Grace for murderers, too.
Grace is for everybody, dear.
Well, then why don’t we say it. (CONTINUED)
Mark --
I’d like to hear it. Everyone looks at McElroy. Wade snorts a laugh.

God, our Father, Lord and Savior, thank you for your love and favor. Please bless this drink and food we pray. Bless all who... (glancing at Wade) ...who shares with us today. Amen. Wade looks up at McElroy who’s watched him throughout... ...the others start eating their dinners. William glances Wade constantly. Mark just stares at the outlaw suspiciou
You know, if my pa wants to, he can shoot you dead. He can shoot a jack rabbit at fifty yards.
Shooting animals is a lot different to shooting a man, son.
No, it isn’t. Not in my opinion. Silence promptly falls in the room. WADE (CONT’D) Ask Byron here. He’s killed dozens of people. Men, women and children. Miners. Apache.
There’s not a soul I’ve taken didn’t deserve what it got. Just the answer Wade was hoping for.
See, when it comes to killing, Byron McElroy doesn’t think in terms of man or woman or even child... (MORE) (CONTINUED)
WADE (cont'd) (pause) ...-he thinks of souls.
Corrupted souls. Like yours. I fight the devil on earth.
As a bounty hunter for the Pinkerton Detective agency and eighteen dollars a day plus expenses.
Yes sir.

Every way of man is right in his own eyes, Byron. The Lord pondereth the heart. (meets eyes with Alice) Proverbs... twenty one. William smiles. Wade glances at the boy and contentedly l down to his plate. He tries to eat his meat. But its not up and, with his hands cuffed, not possible... He meets e with Alice.
.-Dan. Dan sighs and rises from the table. Takes the plate from Wade’s CUFFED HANDS... and cuts the steak.
Thank you, Dan. Would you mind cutting the fat off too, please... (off Dan’s look) ...I don’t like fat. There is a pause at the table as everyone just watches Da dicing the meat.
...Mind if I ask how you got that hitch in your step, Dan?
Don’t tell him nothing, Evans.
‘Where were you stationed? (CONTINUED)
Dan hands the plate to Wade.
.»..-Second Company Sharpshooters out of Lynnfield, Massachusetts. Wade smiles appreciatively. Dan crosses back his seat. (CONTINUED)
My father was defending the United States capitol in the District of Columbia.

...Is that so. (beat) So what happened, Dan. To your leg, I mean. Dan looks to Alice. William looks to his father. Then-- BANG! BANG!...shots coming from the porch. Butterfield stands, frightened. McElroy crosses to the window. Dan waves his wife and children to stay where the are. He looks to the door, his rifle in his hands. MORE SHOTS. Wade, amused, just sits there, chained to his chair and the cast iron stove.
Dan busts out the door to find-- Doc Potter, firing his R into the darkness as Tucker moves to stop him.
Doc... Stop!

....There’s something moving out there behind the rocks. ...McElroy and Butterfield arrive in the door-- as they a look out, a wind blows a dead tree on a nearby hill. Tuck snatches Doc Potter’s rifle.
Inside, the boys have crossed to windows to watch the men argue outside. Wade looks to Alice.
Ever been to San Francisco? (CONTINUED)
If it’s all right by you, Mister Wade, I’d rather we not talk.
So you’ve never been to San Francisco.
-no.

I knew a girl there... Daughter of a sea captain. And she had these beautiful green eyes, the greenest eyes I’ve ever seen. Like yours. And I would look deep into those eyes and well, they’d just change colors right in front of me. All the colors of the sea. He stares into Alice’s green eyes and she can’t look away
What’d you say your name was?
Alice. Alice snaps out of his gaze. Wade’s satisfaction is clear He watches Dan cross to the back of the house as Alice follows.
Dan slams the BEDROOM DOOR behind Alice. He gives her at look, then begins packing a SADDLE BAG.
...For God’s sake. He’s killed more people than the drought.
He’s not what I expected. He’s--
--dangerous. Dangerous is what he is, Alice-- and you and the boys are not going to talk to him again. Alice crosses to the dresser. Dan watches her. She’s upse (CONTINUED)
You can change your mind. No one will think less of you.
No one can think less of me. He looks at her, then looks out the window.

Six months from now, everything’s gonna be green, Alice. Cattle’s gonna be fat. We’ll see the steam from the trains over the ridge. We’ll be all right. Maybe better. But we won’t make it through the next six days if I don’t do this. The door opens--
Sorry, Dan,.. Mister McElroy says five minutes. And closes it. Alice looks to Dan.
You think he’s too much for me?
He’s a killer, Daniel.
Then someone ought to have the decency to bring him to justice.
...What are you thinking.
I’m not out there alone. (touches her) Have a little faith in me.

Ben Wade has a gang, Dan. And they are out there tonight. Somewhere. DAN (CONT’ D) If I don’t go, we’ve got to pack and leave, heading for God-knows-— where, dirt poor, without a prayer. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

DAN (CONT’D) I’m tired of watching the boys go hungry. I’m tired of the way they look at me. I’m tired of the way you don’t. I’ve been standing on one leg for three damned years, waiting for God to do me a favor, Alice. He isn’t listening. It’s up to me. ...there’s a polite KNOCK on the BEDROOM DOOR.
Mister Evans. We’re leaving now.
The group is saddling up. Wade moves to his black horse, Tucker abruptly cuts him off. A smirk across his face...
No, no, no. This’s my horse now. ...and Wade just stares at him, then mounts another horse
(to the group) So where are we headed?

Ain’t none of your business where we’re headed. You’re a prisoner, Wade. You don’t speak, you don’t piss, you don’t goddamn breathe without our say-so. Understand? McElroy rides up, firing a look at Tucker.
We’re going to Contention. We’re putting you on the 3:10 to Yuma, day after tomorrow.
Shouldn’t have told him that.
Relax, friend. Now, if we get separated, I’11 know where to meet up. Tucker glares at McElroy who just rides on. (CONTINUED)
ANGLE ON: DAN emerges onto the porch with Alice. Their so are waiting for them. Dan looks both of them in the eyes. He can see Will’s attention is drawn by Wade.
Don’t be any trouble, Mark.
Yes, Sir.
And William--
I want to come with you.
Well, You can’t.
--I can help.
You’re fourteen years old.
I can ride faster and shoot better than any one of them. The Pinkerton is hurt and Potter’s no good, that railroad man is dead weight and that other bastard--
--William.

I don’t have time to argue. I need you here. ANGLE ON: WADE, watching the Evans family. William takes last look his way and storms into the house. Dan embraces Alice and Mark goodbye and climb onto his horse. He moves embrace her and her eyes flick to Wade, self-conscious. REVERSE-- CLOSE ON DAN-- as they break apart, Wade trots loop around Dan past Alice, politely tipping his hat.
Appreciate your hospitality, mam. I hope I can send your husband back all right. (CONTINUED)

Alice says nothing. Wade grins, then follows the others u McElroy’s vigilant eye. THE GROUP rides away from the ranch... .»..asS Alice, Will and Mark remain on the porch, watchin disappear into the moonlit hills. INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM, EVANS RANCH - NIGHT Alice is now putting the boys to bed. Mark is coughing ha It is a deep hacking that clearly isn’t normal, although Alice and William don’t seem alarmed. Alice gives hima measured spoonful of medicine. It’s all very routine.
What’d Ben Wade mean about sending Pa back all right. Was he saying he was gonna kill him?
He won’t have to lift a finger. His gang will do it. They’ re the most deadly outfit in the whole frontier. Alice shoots William a look.

Your father can take care of himself, Mark. Ben Wade likes to talk. Alice turns off a lamp... -..a moment after she closes the door, William sits up in bed, still dressed. Mark sits up and watches his brother. William pulls a PACKED HAVERSACK from under his bed. Chec on the RATIONS he’s wedged inside. We see an old SIX SHOO PISTOL stuck in there... ..-he glances at Mark, then quietly opens his window.
The group is now following the CATTLE TRAIL up a spur. St light the Heavens above for miles around. It’s beautiful. (CONTINUED)

...but nobody bothers to notice. The lawmen have their ey on the hills around. Checking every shadow and shape. Whi Wade just looks bored. His gaze falls on Tucker riding his BLACK HORSE... ...and a smile creases the outlaw’s face. He gives a GENT WHISTLE, almost inaudible. And the his horse abruptly sto Tucker digs his heels, but the magnificent horse refuses budge until Wade gives another GENTLE WHISTLE. Tucker gla at Wade and he just does it again... ...and again Wade’s horse stops dead. Tucker fights the h but it’s clear Wade has total control. Stopping and start amusing himself.
Wade. Wade whistles once more to get the horse going again, the leaves Tucker alone. There’s a smile under McElroy’s scow

You really think the Marshal’s plan is gonna work, Byron. I gotta confide in you. I don’t. McElroy says nothing. WADE (CONT’D) My crew knows all the back roads to Fort Huachuca. They’11l catch the marshal by daybreak.
What makes you so sure they’11 come for you, Wade. Why should they. Wade smiles.
They’11l be coming. They’re lost without him. Like a pack of dogs without a master. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
MCELROY (cont'd) ...Doc Potter is pale with concern. WADE (CONT’D) Have another drink, Doc.
I gave that up six years ago. I’ma changed man now. A righteous man.

Trouble the righteous have is being able to know right from wrong. Doc Potter stares at Wade, unable to answer. All of a sudden, McElroy turns to look back at-- A FIGURE following them on horseback about four hundred y back along a ridge... ...the rider seems to be following the group. Disappearin around bends or behind trees, only to reappear on the tra few moments later. McElroy looks to Butterfield who is alarmed.
Jesus, no. Not so soon... Dan looks to McElroy who stops his horse. The group insta goes on the alert. Weapons up. Fingers on triggers. The FIGURE keeps riding towards them.
Off your horses. Move it. Everyone obediently does as he says... (CONTINUED)

...Tucker roughly yanks Wade down to the dirt. Doc Potter helps McElroy. Butterfield gathers the horses by the rein Dan, McElroy, and Tucker take up firing positions behind rocks and hedges. Eyes on the cattle trail. Weapons ready ...finally, the LONE FIGURE appears around the bend. ANGLE ON: TUCKER as he goes to shoot. Out of nowhere, Dan clamps a hand down over his rifle.
It’s my son...
Now is that the quiet one or the one that doesn’t shut up. Dan shoots him a look, then approaches William.
I told you to stay home.
I left home. I’m on my own now.

Goddammit, William. This’s no time for games. You turn around. Now. Dan gathers his horse. The others respectfully keeping th distance and riding on with him. Leaving William behind.. ...we HOLD ON: WILLIAM upon his horse, not turning around
They’ re cresting a ridge now. And William’s still follow them a few hundred yards back. Dan brews with frustration ...not realizing that Wade is riding nearby, watching him
It’s a difficult age. Between the hay and the grass, my old man used to say.
He’s stubborn. (CONTINUED)
Well, you can’t plant a radish and get an onion.
Don’t talk to me like you know me, Wade. We ain’t friends.
Only a stubborn man would keep his family on a dying ranch.
...He’s trying to help. He thinks he’s looking out for his old man.

(smiles) You know why I’m so hard to lock away, Dan? People like me. Farmers give me shelter. Cattlemen give me food. Judges let me off. Jailers let me out. Law-abiding citizens out there feels strangled by their shitty little lives. And me... (grins) ...well, I’m like the bird that should never be caged. Wade glances back at William...

Your boy isn’t protecting you. He’s following me. ...and he rides on. Dan watching him. EXT. WILLIAM’S CAMP, CATTLE TRAIL - NIGHT William cooks his supper on a CAMPFIRE later that night. horse is unsaddled nearby. He burrows into his HAVERSACK pulls out a well-read DIME NOVEL. INSERT: THE DIME NOVEL featuring a SILHOUETTED OUTLAW on cover. A smoking pistol in each hand. Rain falling in she under the lurid title: “THE OUTLAW’S REVENGE!” William consumes the pages of the DIME NOVEL with an exci grin, glancing at a FLICKERING LIGHT on the trail ahead..  78 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 48.

...it’s the group’s CAMPFIRE. Everyone’s asleep, except f Wade who’s staring up at the endless blanket of stars and who’s got the watch. We see Dan remove the ANTIQUE BROOCH from his pocket, gaz at it a moment or two. Rubbing it gently with his fingers
...SO were you conscripted into Lincoln’s army, Mr. Evans? Or a volunteer?
Neither. Maybe both.
What’s that mean?
I was a volunteer in the Massachusetts State guard. Then, in ‘62, the Federal government was running low on men so they called in state militias. To protect Washington.
And you got hurt. Dan says nothing.
What are you doing out here, Dan? You got a family at home. You’re not a lawman. You don’t work for the Railroad. Or Pinkerton.
Maybe I don’t like the idea of men like you on the loose.
It’s man’s nature to take what he wants. That’s how we’re born.
Well. I make an honest living. (CONTINUED)
Maybe honest. But I don’t think it’s a living. You must be hurting bad for money if you took this job.
Go to sleep.
I have to imagine being in debt puts pressure on a marriage.
What would you know about marriage. We can’t all be cut-throats and thieves.

I know if I was lucky enough to have a wife like Alice, I’d treat her a whole lot better than you do, Dan. I’d feed her better. Buy her pretty dresses. I wouldn’t make her work so hard... (beat) ...yeah, I’1l bet Alice was a real pretty girl before she married you. ...and Dan just explodes, his RIFLE in Wade’s face.
Shut up about my wife. You say one more word about her and I’11 cut you down right here. Right here.
I like this side of you, Dan.

Mister Evans. Dan glances aside at Doc Potter... ...he’s staring at Dan from under his BLANKET. After a moment, Dan lowers his rifle. His hands are shaki His breath calming. Wade watches him cautiously. Tucker has also woken up, picking up his own rifle.
Okay... It’s my watch. (CONTINUED)
Dan finds a place to sleep as far from Wade as he can get ...as he turns away, we see McElroy under his blanket qui putting the safety on his SHOTGUN. Butterfield sleeps.
Everyone’s asleep now except for Tucker who is sitting ne Wade, his RIFLE leveled at him as he sings to himself...
...yes, they’re gonna hang me in the morning, before this night is done. They’re gonna hang me in the morning and I’ll never see the sun. ...and Wade just glares at him lethally.
I suppose it’s too much to ask for a little quiet.

I'd be asleep in my bed if it weren’t for you. So if I got to be up, you’re damn well gonna be up with me, Ben Wade. (singing) I wanna warn you fellas, tell you one by one -- what makes a gallows rope to swing is a woman and a gun. Wade rolls over, simmering. We see him discreetly remove length of COPPER WIRING from his jacket, twisting it tigh around both his hands like a shiv...
...a strange GURGLING NOISE wakes Dan an hour later in th dawn light. He focuses on the noise to see Wade kneeling Tucker. Dan scrambles.
Jesus! In the next moment, McElroy lunges at Wade from out of nowhere with the butt of his shotgun. Wade falls off Tuck Dropping the COPPER SHIV. (CONTINUED)

The others begin to stir now, reacting with shock and hor to what Wade’s done. Tucker’s throat has been cut. Doc Po rushes over and searches for a pulse... ...he doesn’t find one. His hands close Tucker’s eyes. SMACK! McElroy boots Wade savagely in the face. The outla tumbles. And now McElroy starts to beat Wade, his vigorou movements re-opening his own wounds. Butterfield and Doc Potter hurry to pull McElroy back. Wade notices Dan deliberately hanging back... ...and a grin creases his bloody, battered face. That spu Dan forward, pulling McElroy back with sudden force.
That’s enough, Mister McElroy. McElroy stops, if only because he’s exhausted and weak... ...-he returns to Tucker and retrieves the HAND CUFFS KEY Wade sits up, nursing his wounds and staring at Dan.
(re: Tucker) We have to bury him.
You take the time to dig one grave, you might as well dig two. And with that, the group reluctantly saddles up. Wade ret to his horse, whispering to it soothingly. Reclaiming it.

An AMERICAN FLAG droops over the sprawling army barracks Fort Huachuca. The dawn sun glinting over the still sleep town. About a mile away, we find... ...a SMALL SPECK racing through a canyon towards the town
It’s the prison wagon. Marshal Weathers looks exhausted a sits on top, whipping his TEAM OF HORSES through the cany (CONTINUED)

Crawley keeps a frightened eye out through the PRISON BAR the wagon. A weary smile creasing his face when he spots Huachuca in the distance. The marshal reaches for his WATER CAN... ...BANG! The shot almost takes his head off. Marshal Weathers tumbles from the PRISON WAGON, falling r past Crawley’s eyes as he smashes lifelessly into a CACTU ANGLE ON: CAMPOS retracting his SNIPER RIFLE from his per behind a LARGE BOULDER. Charlie Prince pats him on the ba watching as the PRISON WAGON HORSES slow to a grateful ha ANGLE ON: CRAWLEY trapped inside the PRISON WAGON. His PI drawn as he peers out the PRISON BARS either side of him. ...the gang materializes out of the rocks and canyon crev now (PRINCE, CAMPOS, SUTHERLAND, JACKSON). Swarming aroun the PRISON WAGON like bees on a hive. It seems they’re st unaware of the switch.

Get you outta there in a second, boss. Don’t you worry. Jackson grabs the PADLOCK KEY off the MARSHAL’S BELT, giv it to Charlie Prince who then goes to open the PADLOCK... ...BANG! Crawley catches Charlie Prince with a taut shot. outlaw stumbles backwards. Bleeding from his neck. The bu just scraping him. The other outlaws spot Crawley inside... ...they draw their guns, ready to finish him.

Wait. He gives a nod to Sutherland who quickly frees the horses from the wagon. Now Sutherland sets the PRISON WAGON on fire... ...the smoke and flames swiftly engulf the old wooden WAG Charlie Prince stays close. Eyes on Crawley who starts to panic inside.
Oh, Jesus... Oh, no. (CONTINUED)
Charlie lunges and grabs Wades’ black hat off his head. He dusts it off as the flames rise in the coach.
Where is he.
Open the door. Let me out of here, goddammit.
Where’d they take him.
I don’t know.
Mister, you better tell me where they took him or you will burn. The smoke is choking Crawley now... ...the flames rising higher every second.
Contention... All right. They took him to Contention. Gonna catch the 3:10 to Yuma Prison tomorrow.
You ain’t lying now.
I ain’t lying. I swear to God. Now let me out of here. The gang watches Charlie Prince carefully... He turns his back on Crawley in the burning coach.
Contention’s eighty miles back the other way.
We’d have to about kill our horses.
So we’1ll buy new ones. (CONTINUED)

Charlie. It was his own fault he got caught. He made a mistake. He was weak. Charlie turns red faced toward Crawley, still moaning fro the burning coach. BANG-- BANG. He fires two shots, silen Crawley, then turns back to Jackson.
...You think you could do a better job leading this crew? Do you?

Maybe. Yeah. Charlie Prince lunges quickly at Jackson, smashing his fa with his pistol, knocking him to the ground, straddling h He levels his two SCHOFIELDS in Jackson’s face. Glancing the others. Nez steps to his side.

You forgotten what you were before Ben Wade come along. You forgotten what he did for us. (pause) We’re going to Contention. And with that, Charlie Prince remounts his horse... ...and GALLOPS back the other way. The others follow in o and twos. Jackson goes last, not liking this.
