text: WADE’S GANG RIDES HARD at full gallop. They are headed ba toward Bisbee, dust flying in a cloud behind them. We see town of Bisbee in the distance. Charlie Prince leads the gang into the mountains.

William sits on his horse, staring at something in shock. ...it’s the body of Tucker. Slumped by the SMOULDERING CA FIRE. There’s some confusion in William’s eyes. It’s as i doesn’t quite know how to feel. (CONTINUED)
Just now, he notices several SMALL SPECKS riding towards on the plains below. He spurs his horse onwards up the tr

BINOCULAR POV: THE BEN WADE GANG riding hard and fast acr the endless Arizona plains, perhaps fifty or so miles awa ANGLE ON: McELROY sitting on his horse on a high promonto The others grouped around him. McElroy lowers his BINOCUL his grim face says it all. Wade smirks.
Can’t say I didn’t warn you.
There’s a shortcut we could take.
Shortcut.
Through the pass. Takes you right through to Contention.
Why didn’t you tell us this before.
It’s Apache country.
I thought the government gave them land.
These are the ones refused to go.
I wouldn’t take that pass.
You’d rather us take the long way.
That’s right.
--and let your boys catch us. (CONTINUED)
The Apache are skilled warriors and marksmen. Even worse, these are the stubborn ones who stayed to fight. You won’t make it. McElroy looks through his BINOCULARS again.
We’1l1 take our chances.

CLOSE ON: A PAIR OF DEAD, WHITE MINERS lying by the side the trail. Their heads have been scalped. Their bodies le to rot in the hot sun... ...we find William staring quietly at the corpses as he r past. About a mile ahead, we can see the rest of the grou They are on the opposite side of a spreading ravine.
The group is now riding above a ravine. The scenery here spectacular, if a little precarious... Dan rides up to Wade, looking at him for a moment.
Something on your mind, Dan.
Why’d you kill Tucker. ...Why not me. Or Butterfield.
Tucker took my horse. (beat) ...Did you like him, Dan?
No. He was an asshole. But wishing him dead and killing him are two different things. Wade watches Dan ride ahead. After a beat, Wade catches up to him. (CONTINUED)
Your conscience is sensitive, Dan. I don’t think it’s my favorite part of you. Just now, McElroy falls back beside them.
Shut your mouth, Wade. From here out, you want to talk to someone, talk to me.
I don’t like talking to you, Byron.
Not when I have the gun.
No. It’s not that. (pause) You're just not very interesting. Doc snorts a laugh.
That’s right, Doc. Laugh it up. Until he guts you like a fish.
Byron’s like a song with one note. (turns) ‘You ever read a book in your life besides the bible, Byron?
No need.
(turns to Dan) Byron acts pious, but a couple years back, when he was under contract to the Central, I seen him and some Pinks mow down thirty two Apache, women and children.
Insurgents was cutting down the railroad men and their families. Picking them one by one off the road. Scalping them. (CONTINUED)

There was little ones running around crying and screaming. No more than three years old. And his boys shot them all and pushed them in a ditch, some still crying. I guess Byron figured that was fine with Jesus, because apparently Jesus don’t like the Apache. The terrain is getting steeper.
Keep talking, Wade. All the way to Yuma. Up them steps. To the rope. And straight to hell.
The day I die, Byron, I’m getting sprung from hell. Riding in the rear, Dan senses there is someone following them. Up front, McElroy looks to Butterfield.
...I guess maybe I’d feel the same way if I come from the seed of a drunk grave digger and the rancid womb of a whore. McElroy grins. Wade is silent. Eyes dark.
Quiet for once. (looking back) What’s wrong, Wade? ‘Cat got your tongue? Afraid of heights?

No. I’m afraid the Apache on the ridge might shoot me. McElroy whirls around, SHOTGUN raised... ...-BEHIND HIM, WADE LAUNCHES. LEAPING OFF HIS SADDLE. CRASH-TACKLING the Pinkerton with a stunning body-blow. They both fall to the ground. Sliding on the steep rock. (CONTINUED)
Dan leaps for his rifle but both Doc, frozen, and Butterf fumbling with his pistol, and their spinning horses are i the way. It given Wade the moment he needs-- TO LEVEL MCELROY’S SHOTGUN AT DAN.

Drop it, Dan. Drop it! (to Doc and Butterfield) Toss yours down. Wade is fiercely angry, eyes a flame. Dan tosses his rifl down. Doc and Butterfield also comply. Then, Wade turns h a stirring McElroy brutally with the rifle butt. McElroy is delirious as Wade loops his hand-cuffs around boot and drags him to the edge of the ravine. WADE (CONT’D) ...I always liked you, Byron. But you’ve never known when to shut up. He kneels down to the tough old man’s face and pulls him upright. McElroy glares at him.
Even bad men love their momma. And with that, he shoves McElroy off the edge-- Everyone watches as his body flails, flying downward. Wade turns and points the shotgun at Dan and the others.

Okay. ...Now its time for everyone to go home. But there is a click of a gun, and, all of a sudden, Wade finds himself feeling the barrel of WILLIAM'S OLD PISTOL his ear. It is tightly gripped in William’s two hands.
Don’t move, mister Wade. And let go of that shotgun.
William... Wade grins at William and the quivering pistol. He doesn’ raise his hands. Doesn’t even seem to be concerned. (CONTINUED)

You’ re not gonna shoot a man you admire in the back of the head, boy. I’m not sure you even know how to work that thing. BANG! The bullet zips past Wade’s ear, takes down a tree branch... ...-Ben Wade’s grin promptly disappears.
Dan. Tell your son it’s over. The Pinkerton’s dead. Let’s go our separate ways. You got spread too thin. Its nothing to be ashamed of.
Think you can keep your gun on him, William.

I’m doing a damn sight better than you did. Dan smiles and crosses to his rifle in the dirt. He picks it up, cocks it and aims at Wade. The outlaw sighs, begrudgingly impressed. Butterfield’s pleased. Doc Potter’s relieved...

WADE, WILLIAM, BUTTERFIELD, DAN and DOC POTTER have campe the middle of a massive field of TALL BROWN GRASS which s softly in the night breeze... ...everybody’s hunkered down in a tight circle. Sharing s PIECES OF BREAD and a WATER CANTEEN as they keep a vigila watch through the grass. (CONTINUED)
Wade notices William nervously shuffling his DECK OF CARD
Your Pa ever take you to some of the towns up north? Breckinridge. Buena Vista. Leadville?
No.
I tell you one thing... They know how to shuffle cards in Leadville.
Stop talking to him.
I had the best Irish whiskey I ever tasted there. A dollar a glass. ...There was women in those towns who could do things you’d never forget.
Give you a disease you’d never forget.

With money in your pocket you could have whatever a man desired or needed. I learned everything I know there. Landed there no older than you. On my own. And I left with the start of my gang. (CONTINUED)
+e OF +e eH OF  3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 62.
A wistful smile washes over the outlaw’s face.
‘Course, its all gone now. Silver crashed, and then the railroad changed everything.
For the better I am sure. The awed look in William’s eyes is killing Dan... ..Clearly, he doesn’t talk with William like this.
...How many men you think you’ve killed since you set out with your gang, Wade? How many families you think you destroyed. Hundreds?
Quite a few. I’m a bad man, Dan.
I heard you dynamited a wagon full of prospectors last Spring.
Now that’s a lie... (to William) ...it was a train full. William smiles... ...and Dan is crushed.
I have to go, Dan.
You ain’t going nowhere.
(shakes his head) No. I mean I have to go.
Dan escorts Wade through the TALL GRASS a short way from camp. The SHOTGUN in his hands, alert for threats. (CONTINUED)
I’d appreciate it if you wouldn’t fill his head with stories of death and sin.
No use hiding the world, Dan. He’s trying to decide which way to go.
He’1l decide better without more from you.
I thought he was gonna shoot me on that ravine. There’s wild in his eyes. Reminds me of--
He’s nothing like you.
The road to corruption is steep and slippery, Dan.
The path of decency is just as steep. Wade steps away and turns his back to Dan, pissing
That’s true, Dan. It is. You do one good deed and feel all decent. (MORE)
(CONTINUED)

WADE (cont'd) I imagine it’s habit forming. Soon, you’re a slave to your decency. You’ re not a man no more. You don’t ever do what you want. Take what you want. You don’t know what you want. You just keep being decent and good till your hollow and dead. Dan’s disturbed by Wade’s words... ...-he gazes through the TALL GRASS back at his son. When Dan turns back around... ...Wade has disappeared. Dan’s horrified. Rushing through the grass. Suddenly, WaDE LEAPS OUT OF THE GRASS AND GRABS DAN, wres him to the ground. Dan manages to lift his SHOTGUN into Wade’s face... Wade is shushing him. Looking up to the rocks. Sensing something out there. BANG! The GUNSHOT comes from nowhere... ...and knocks Dan flat on his back --
-- they hear the shot at the camp. William suddenly runs into the grass with his old PISTOL. The others trying in to stop him -- tee FH HOF

-- more BULLETS fly over Wade’s head as William drops dow beside him, checking on his father. Dan’s wounded. The sh clipped his skull... ...no time to think, Wade and William grab Dan and begin drag him back towards the campsite. GUNSHOTS ripping thro the grass on all sides. Wade catches glimpses of them in the brush. A flash of BA FEATHERS. A swish of RAWHIDE TROUSERS. A glint of a TOMAH

The horses are freaking out. BULLETS whizzing past their as Butterfield and Doc Potter help pull Dan into their ca Dan’s starting to regain his bearings, looking about... ...the GUNFIRE is coming from three sides. They can’t see shooters through the grass. But the GUNFIRE is volcanic. keeps his head low, calculating.
There’s three of them.
Yours.
If they were mine, you’d be dead. Dan struggles to cock his SHOTGUN, woozy... ...the blood seeping into his eyes and blinding him.
Give me a gun.
No.

You want them to scalp your boy. Dan stares at the outlaw, the GUNFIRE drawing closer... ...the others watch from their firing positions, waiting see what Dan’s going to do. Finally, he gives Wade the HA SHOTGUN... (CONTINUED)

...the outlaw checks the TWO SHELLS inside. Then holds ou his hand for more shells. Dan shakes his head, grimacing pain as Doc Potter tries to staunch the bleeding. Wade realizes he’s not getting any more ammo. He scoffs a Dan, then cocks both barrels of the shotgun. Waiting for pause in the SHOOTING... ...then he scrambles away and vanishes into the grass. Th others keep their eyes on the TALL GRASS. Praying. Hoping BOOM! They hear the SHOTGUN roar... ...no more shooting from the left of them. William dares to lift his head. Glancing around at the TA GRASS. Heart in his throat. Waiting. Watching. Lying stil BOOM! Another SHOTGUN BLAST out there... ...no more shooting from the right of them now. Dan keeps his eyes on the RIFLE SHOTS from ahead... ...and then all of a sudden, the rifle stops shooting. Everyone in the camp listens now to the SOUNDS OF A STRUG somewhere out in the grass. Men GRAPPLING and WRESTLING w each other... ...there’s an ABRUPT GASP. The sound of METAL SLICING FLE and the fall of a body to the ground. Then there’s silenc Everybody stares into the swaying TALL GRASS... ...and then, a FIGURE appears. Walking towards them. It’s Ben Wade. Covered in the blood of others. Looking li death incarnate and furious for having been made to kill Apache warriors... ...but most alarming is the fact that Wade now has one of feathered APACHE RIFLES in his MANACLED HANDS. The other are slung over his shoulder. Butterfield reaches for his rifle... ...-but a look from Wade makes his freeze. Now he aims at Dan like he’s going to kill him. (CONTINUED)
I told you not to go this way. I told you there’d be trouble.
It was Mister McElroy’s decision. Wade glances aside at Doc Potter... ...then returns his bitter gaze on Dan.

Give me the key. Dan digs the HAND-CUFFS KEY out of his pocket... ...then hurls it out into the field of tall grass. Everybody watches the key sail through the air, swallowed first by the darkness, then by the endless field of grass ...and Wade just can’t believe it. He zeroes in on Dan. L his rifle. And ruthlessly wallops Dan across the jaw with rifle butt. AND DAN BLACKS OUT.
DAN COMES TO SEVERAL MINUTES LATER. Doc Potter sits him u with William’s help. Butterfield hovers anxiously behind.
Easy does it. Easy.
(weak) Where is he.
He’s gone. Took our horses with him. I found this in the grass. ...it’s the HAMMER SHOTGUN. Taking the gun as he pushes himself to his feet. He’s wobbly, but otherwise fine.
He went that way.
It’s the fastest way out of the pass. He’1l be looking for help getting those cuffs off. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
DAN (cont'd) (to William) Find his tracks, son.
We’re going after him.
There’s no reward for getting him halfway to that train, is there?
No, sir. Doc Potter considers this as Dan loads his SHOTGUN...

ANGLE ON-- BEN WADE as he cautiously approaches a freshly railroad tunnel. BOOM! A LOW RUMBLING EXPLOSION rocks the mountain range and shakes the ground (and vibrates camera Something big is happening on the other side of the tunne OVER BEN as he emerges from the tunnel to see-- DOZENS OF CHINESE WORKERS moving about, laying track. Ten line the graded earth, sprinkled with woks and bowls. (CONTINUED)

A labyrinth of squalid housing. The workers themselves ar thin and beat to hell. They wear umbrella-like hats to wa off the SCORCHING SUN. A cloud from the recent explosion billows in the distance Wade rides cautiously through the camp. He betrays no emotion, perhaps he has none... ...he’s on a mission, his eyes scanning the workers.

CLOSE ON: WALTER BOLES (48) sucking a cigar at his desk a feeds leftover SCRAMBLED EGGS to a PET MONKEY on a leash. ...a Ssleepy-eyed PROSTITUTE lays on a couch behind him a head of the train car. The windows have all been curtaine bookish TELEGRAPH OPERATOR mans the TELEGRAPH CONSOLE nea Three RAILROAD ENFORCERS sit about, including ZEKE (44) w meticulously filing his nails. A BULLWHIP dangles on his Boles feeds his PET MONKEY as Zeke speaks long-sufferingl
Says they want forty dollars each month now. Like them Irish up north. Goddamn Coolies. They’1l work fine with my left boot up their asses.
If I could teach a monkey to lay track...
What we need’s some Negroes brung in here, Mister Boles. Show these Chinamen what real work is. Just now, Boles sees -- Wade riding outside... ...sifting through the DUSTY HAZE like a ghost.
Holy Christ...
What. What is it.
(pause) That’s him.  98 99 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 70.

A TENT FLAP abruptly peels back to reveal Wade in the ope of a CHINESE FAMILY’s tent. A APACHE RIFLE in his hands.. ...there are several people inside. A MATRIARCH. Three YO DAUGHTERS. And a GRANDMOTHER. All of them go still when W enters their tent. Wade scans the tent for threats, noticing a HAMMER and CH lying on a stool. He closes the TENT FLAP and advances on frightened family... ...pointing to his HAND-CUFFS and the HAMMER and CHISEL.

You. Break the hand-cuffs. You help me. With the hammer. Without warning, a VOLLEY OF GUNFIRE rips into the small from every direction. Dishes explode and splinters fly... ...the CHINESE FAMILY hits the dirt with Wade. The MATRIA pinning her screaming daughters to the ground. Wade glances at the CHINESE FAMILY who seem unhurt, but terrified, the children screaming in Chinese. BOLES O.S. I got five guns on you out here, Ben Wade. You best come on out

Dan leads our dwindling group through the first tunnel an into the blasting camp, staring at the conditions of the CHINESE WORKERS. ...we notice William caught by the haunted eyes of a teen CHINESE WORKER hauling a basket full of rocks past the gr

The horses. He’s pointing at the TRAIN CAR where their horses are hit to a post. THEY HEAR A MAN SCREAM INSIDE... ...the train car is perched on some rails in the middle o the camp. Two TELEGRAPH WIRES connect the car to a chain TELEGRAPH POLES.  100 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 71.

CLOSE ON: WADE as Zeke SHOCKS his BARE TORSO with an EXPO WIRE that extends from A BLASTING BOX... ...the two other RAILROAD ENFORCERS gather around with Bo and the TELEGRAPH OPERATOR. The PROSTITUTE is in the wind

What the hell is going on here. The two RAILROAD ENFORCERS whirl around with their guns.. ...and our group stops instantly. Dan lowers his SHOTGUN. glances at Wade. And the exhausted outlaw just smiles bac
Mister Butterfield.
Mister Boles.

All finished in Bisbee. (no reply) Better hurry. We making the last blasts through the mountain this week, Butterfield nods, tense. Boles waltzes over to him now... ...the two men face to face, which unsettles Butterfield.
So what’re you doing in my neck of the woods, Mister Butterfield.
That’s our prisoner. We’re taking him to Contention. Putting him on the prison train to Yuma.
What prisoner. I don’t see anybody that’s a prisoner.
Come now, Mister Boles. That’s Ben Wade you have there. (CONTINUED)
Ben Wade gunned down my kid brother in front of me. Six years ago in Abilene.

Your brother was a lying, bilking card sharp. That is, if he’s the asshole I remember. He could, of course, have been another asshole I killed who I forgot about. Boles flushes red, glancing at Zeke... ...who SHOCKS Wade again. Wade just glares at Zeke, buryi the pain. And there’s a sudden pang of fear in Zeke’s eye He stops and Wade finally slumps, held up only by his HAN CUFFS which are looped over a hook attached to the train. Dan glances aside at William.. ...wishing he didn’t have to see that.
You can’t do this. It’s immoral.
Morals got nothing to do with it.
(pause) I was expecting to collect two hundred dollars reward for that man.
That’s too bad, rancher.
No. Its not. I have to deliver him to Contention. I need that money.
You need it bad enough to die. Dan feels the RAILROAD ENFORCER’s guns on him... ...he st at Wade, then finally relents.
At least, let us have our horses. (CONTINUED)
I’ve got no problem with that. So long as you ride away. (pause) Ride away, rancher.

Nice knowing you, Dan. Dan locks eyes with Wade as the others retrieve their hor and ride back up to Dan. Boles doesn’t move, watching Dan ...a last look at Wade and Dan turns to his horse. Nobody notices Doc Potter pulling a SHOVEL out of a pile rocks. He hefts the tool and swings it with all his might ...WHACK! Straight into a RAILROAD ENFORCER’s face. The man tumbles backwards, cradling his BLOODY NOSE. Dan seizes the moment, spinning around. Catching Boles in stomach with a powerful right-hand punch. Boles doubles o gaping for air... ...it’s all happening so quick, William doesn’t know what going on. He glimpses Wade using his HAND-CUFFS to lift h legs and kick Zeke in the chest. The TELEGRAPH OPERATOR drops his pistol and runs... ...while the other RAILROAD ENFORCER fires a shot at Dan. shot misses. Dan quickly lays a right hook across Boles’ William spurs his horse forward at the RAILROAD ENFORCER. ...who ducks aside just in time. Butterfield rides up to with his black horse and the outlaw clambers aboard.
Dan takes the lead as the group races through the busy ca heading for the tunnel. CHINESE WORKERS jump aside, clear a path for them...
...meanwhile, Boles and Zeke and the two RAILROAD ENFORCE regroup fast. Leaping onto their horses and giving chase.  103 104 105 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 74.
Like mice navigating a maze, the two groups weave through endless rows of tents. BOLES’ GROUP shooting at DAN’S GRO

CHINESE WORKERS stream in and out of the tunnel, moving r in WHEELBARROWS. Some leading PACK MULES with sacks strap across their backs... ...they scramble out of the way as Dan and his group barr past into the tunnel. Boles and the RAILROAD ENFORCERS ar close behind, GUNS BLAZING.
CHINESE WORKERS jump to the sides of the tunnel for safet ...the GUNSHOTS echoing like cannon blasts within the nar walls. Oddly, Doc Potter’s got a Cheshire grin on his fac
You see me get that one with the shovel. But before Dan can reply, Doc Potter gasps with pain... ...a BULLET striking him between the shoulders.

Doc. He begins to fall off his horse... ...-but William grabs him, keeping him on. They emerge from one tunnel and enter another as-- BOLES closes in from one hundred feet behind, lining up f another shot as he rides. Zeke and the other two are only length behind Boles. ANGLE ON: WADE spotting A CRATE OF TNT lying before the n tunnel. Hanging low off his horse, WADE SCOOPS A BUNDLE O DYNAMITE --AND TURNS TO DAN.
If I throw this, can you shoot it? (CONTINUED)
Dan’s answer is cock his rifle. He pulls up his horse to William, Butterfield and Doc rip past. Wade also pulls up heaving the TNT bundle toward--

BANG! Dan fires! And they ride like hell as-- KABOOM! IT BLOWS. Dan and Wade spur their horses and just escape the fiery breath of the explosion and the BOULDERS that fall from above. The tunnel caves in behind them... ...cutting off Boles and his group who’s horses buck from explosion. Boles is singed from the fire and livid, glari at the impasse.
Goddammit!

Dan and his group ride out the other end of the tunnel. W collapses on his horse, the effects of his torture catchi up with him now... ...before he knows it, Dan snatches the HAMMER SHOTGUN ba and loads a pair of shells. He gives it to Butterfield. A helps William ease Doc Potter out of his saddle. They lay under the shade of a nearby tree.
(fading) Did we do it. Did we get away.

Yeah, Doc... Thanks to you. Doc Potter smiles, then his body goes limp... ...and Dan just stares at him. Wade watches this. William’s eyes follow -- The half-built tracks that threa into the valley and finally to THE SPRAWLING LOW CITY OF CONTENTION TEN MILES OFF. Dan’s eyes are heavy. The last forty-eight hours are star to take their toll. Wade studies him.

Meanwhile, Boles and the others exit their end of the tun Limping back into the camp. Boles barks orders about gett their horse to the other side. As they emerge from the tunnel, Boles suddenly stops talking. WHAT THEY SEE: Charlie Prince and the other outlaws. Perc upon their exhausted, sweat-stained horses, they circle through the camp and come to a stop at the entrance to th tunnel... ...they look exhausted, been riding all night.
...Who are you.
We’re looking for a group escorting an outlaw by the name of Ben Wade.
...Shit, they just passed through here.
That so.
We were chasing them through the tunnel.
We’re going after them, ‘you want to join us.
What’s it to you.
Ben Wade shot my brother. In Abilene. Six years ago.
Then your brother must be famous. This draws some smiles on the outlaws...
You boys some kind of posse, huh. (CONTINUED)

You could say that. ...and Charlie Prince draws his two SCHOFIELDS. They roar as one, catapulting Boles off his horse... ...the rest of the gang immediately opens up on Zeke and two RAILROAD ENFORCERS. Riddling them with DOZENS OF BULL which knock them all to the ground. THE CHINESE WORKERS cease what they’re doing, staring at scene. The entire camp frozen as if time has stopped. Charlie Prince holsters his guns.
I hate posses. He glances at Jackson and Jackson nods... ...and the gang rides up towards the mountain.

As the group rides through town, they see nothing but WHO HOUSES and SALOONS and shops. Stores have IRON BARS on th windows, and there’s not a church to be found. DRUNKS lay about in the shade. A HORSEMAN pukes while hol his horse. Another one takes an endless piss in a back al Wade catches Dan’s horrified eyes and just smiles... ...we see that William is just as surprised as his father The MARSHAL’S OFFICE is right across the street... ...the door is barred. A sign reads: “CLOSED FOR REPAIRS”

Congratulations, Dan. You made it. Contention City. The future of Bisbee. In all its glory. Six blocks away, beyond a cattle yard-- THE NEW TRAIN DEP A clock tower above tells us its quarter to one. (CONTINUED)
We need a place to lay low. Keep him out of sight till the train comes.
There’s a hotel this way. You ride PAN TO REVEAL-- A fancy hotel sits on Main Street, the tallest building in the town. Butterfield leads them towa it...
I’ll check us in. You keep riding and amble round back.
Dan and the others dismount at the back entrance of the hotel. It’s quieter here. A few TOWNSMEN walking past at mouth of the alley. None of them seem to notice Wade.
(to William) Keep a watch by the rail head. If you see them coming --
-- I’l1l1 let you know.
(pause) William. The boy looks back at his father... ...but Dan just smiles and William nods and rides off. Wade sees the pride in Dan’s eyes. They notice a COOL WIND picking up now.

William does a thorough reconnaissance of the obnoxious t trotting down ALLEYS and eyeballing SUSPICIOUS CHARACTERS ..-he’s taking his job very seriously, clutching his PIST  114 115 116 117 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 79.
A DANCE HALL ENTRANCE feeds from the alley where a sign broadcasts the times of performances.
There’s a Can-Can at two, if you’re interested. ...just now, Butterfield opens a BACK DOOR.
The lobby is quiet. A few men at the bar. The BARTENDER i the only one who seems to notice Wade. Watching Butterfie lead them up the stairs.
Butterfield UNLOCKS the door to a room covered in hearts.
It’s the Bridal Suite. Hope you don’t mind, it’s all they had. He gives Dan his golden POCKET WATCH.

I’m going to go see if I can find the marshal. Wade takes a seat on the DOUBLE BED while Dan checks out room. He peels back the CURTAINS to reveal a huge BAY WIN that overlooks the street below. WHAT DAN SEES: A DARK CLOUD BANK building on the horizon the distance. Rain clouds.
Well, would you look at that. ...a flicker of confusion crosses Dan’s face.
William also sees THE RAIN CLOUDS down on the street belo he rides towards the entrance to town. He’s as shocked as is... (CONTINUED)
..-he glances back hesitantly at the hotel, then rides on
Dan gazes at the clouds, then turns to see Butterfield an Wade looking at him.
Still need that two hundred, Dan.
Shut up.
Mister Evans, you continue to give me great confidence.
It ain’t 3:10 yet. Butterfield leaves and Dan LOCKS the door behind him.
Butterfield hurries back down the stairs to the lobby. Ag we notice the BARTENDER watching. Something wrong about h
Dan hangs the POCKET WATCH on a COAT RACK. Wade rests on DOUBLE BED, feeling its bounce as he surveys the small ro

So this’s the bridal suite, huh. I wonder how many brides... Dan just looks at him, unamused. He takes a seat in a ROC CHAIR by the window. Rests the HAMMER SHOTGUN on his lap, rifle close... ...and he just stares out the windows at those blessed cl on the horizon. For the first time in a long time, things actually looking good. Wade reclines on the bed, gazing at the ceiling.
What are you gonna do with your two hundred now that rain’s coming. (CONTINUED)
I owe people money, Wade... The drought left me in the hole.
